entry.emph: Preliminary discovery relating to prospective defendants — Rules 5.1 –5.3

row.entry: These rules provide a limited means of preliminary discovery to enable a party to obtain information necessary either to identify a potential defendant or to determine whether to commence proceedings against a prospective defendant.

entry.emph: Discovery from persons who are not parties — Rule 5.4

row.entry: This rule permits orders for discovery to be made against persons who are not parties to proceedings.
These rules provide ancillary powers relating to discovery, including provision for inspection, costs and expenses, security for costs and the preservation of privilege.

Part 5 does not apply to civil proceedings before the Industrial Relations Commission (when constituted otherwise than as the Industrial Court); or to proceedings in the Local Court, Small Claims Division: UCPR Sch 1.

The rules are partly based on the former SCR Part 3 but add to them with the introduction of a procedure for non-party discovery, to the same effect as that contained in FCR O 15A r 8 (now FCR r 20.23). The rules complement the entitlement to discovery under the general law, which is preserved by r 1.4 of the UCPR.
Absence of sufficient information to decide to commence proceedings ‥ [5.3.15]
Application required to be made on notice ‥ [5.3.20]
Discovery of documents from prospective defendant ‥ [r 5.3]
Discovery to obtain identity of defendant ‥ [r 5.2]
Expenses of applicant and costs orders ‥ [5.8.5]
Form of discovery and obligation to produce for inspection ‥ [5.5.5]
Satisfaction of applicant's entitlement to make the substantive claim ‥ [5.3.5]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 5.1] r 5.1 Definitions (cf Federal Court Rules, Order 15A, rule 1)

leg:heading.title: Definitions (cf Federal Court Rules, Order 15A, rule 1 )

p.text: In this Part:
means an applicant for an order under this Part.

includes the name and (as applicable) the place of residence, registered office, place of business or other whereabouts, and the occupation and sex, of the person against whom the applicant desires to bring proceedings, and also whether that person is an individual or a corporation.
[r 5.1 am Amendment 1 of 2005 r 3 and Sch 1[6], effective 15 August 2005]

Under the general law, proceedings lie for discovery to disclose the name of a wrongdoer: Norwich Pharmacal Co v Customs and Excise Cmrs [1974] AC 133; [1973] 2 All ER 943 ; British Steel Corp v Granada Television Ltd [1981] AC 1096; [1981] 1 All ER 417 ; X Ltd v Morgan-Grampian (Publishers) Ltd [1991] 1 AC 1; [1990] 2 All ER 1 . There are differing views as to how far the inherent jurisdiction authorises wider preliminary discovery in relation to information relevant to the proposed proceedings (as distinct from information exclusively concerned with the identity of the proposed defendant): see Hooper v Kirella Pty Ltd (1999) 96 FCR 1; 167 ALR 358; [1999] FCA 1584; BC9907490 at [28]–[29] . But it will extend to orders to obtain information about the identity of trustees or the nature and location of trust property: Murphy v Murphy [1998] 3 All ER 1; [1999] 1 WLR 282 ; A v C [1981] QB 956; [1980] 2 All ER 347 ; and see the discussion in “Finding out Who to Sue” (1973) 89 LQR 482. The present rules specifically permit discovery directed to either purpose.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 5.2] r 5.2 Discovery to ascertain prospective defendant’s identity or whereabouts (cf Federal Court Rules, Order 15A, rules 3, 5 and 9)

leg:heading.title: Discovery to ascertain prospective defendant’s identity or whereabouts (cf Federal Court Rules, Order 15A, rules 3 , 5 and 9 )

p.text: This rule applies if it appears to the court that:

the applicant, having made reasonable inquiries, is unable to sufficiently ascertain the identity or whereabouts of a person (the person concerned) for the purpose of commencing proceedings against the person, and

some person other than the applicant (the other person) may have information, or may have or have had possession of a document or thing, that tends to assist in ascertaining the identity or whereabouts of the person concerned.
The court may make either or both of the following orders against the other person:
an order that the other person attend the court to be examined as to the identity or whereabouts of the person concerned,

an order that the other person must give discovery to the applicant of all documents that are or have been in the other person’s possession and that relate to the identity or whereabouts of the person concerned.
A court that makes an order for examination under subrule (2)(a) may also make either or both of the following orders:

an order that the other person must produce to the court on the examination any document or thing that is in the other person’s possession and that relates to the identity or whereabouts of the person concerned,
an order that the examination be held before a registrar.
An order under this rule with respect to any information, document or thing held by a corporation may be addressed to any appropriate officer or former officer of the corporation.

A person need not comply with the requirements of an order under subrule (2)(a) unless conduct money has been handed or tendered to the person a reasonable time before the date on which attendance is required.

If the other person incurs expense or loss in complying with an order under subrule (2)(a) , and the expense or loss exceeds the amount paid to the person under subrule (5) , the court may order the applicant to pay to that person an amount sufficient to make good the expense or loss.
Unless the court orders otherwise, an application for an order under this rule:
must be supported by an affidavit stating the facts on which the applicant relies and specifying the kinds of information, documents or things in respect of which the order is sought, and
must, together with a copy of the supporting affidavit, be served personally on the other person.
An application for an order under this rule is to be made:
if it is made in relation to proceedings in which the applicant is a party, by notice of motion in the proceedings, or
in any other case, by summons.
This rule applies, with any necessary modification, where the applicant, being a party to proceedings, wishes to claim or cross-claim against a person who is not a party to the proceedings.
[r 5.2 am Amendment 1 of 2005 r 3 and Sch 1[7], effective 15 August 2005]

What constitutes “reasonable inquiries” will depend on the nature of the information sought and its possible sources. If documents are not forthcoming from one obvious source, inquiries should generally be made to see if the information can be obtained from other potential sources: CGU Insurance Ltd v Malaysia International Shipping Corp Berhad (2001) 187 ALR 279; [2001] FCA 1223; BC200105976 . However “reasonable inquiries” is an impressionistic criterion. Whether an applicant in any particular case has failed to make a reasonable attempt to identify and use alternative sources of information will depend on the nature of the information sought, the postulated source and the means of obtaining the information. The mere potential availability of the information, for example, as a result of a Freedom of Information Act request, does not in itself make it unreasonable to claim an alternative remedy under this rule: Hughes Aircraft Systems International v Civil Aviation Authority (1995) 217 ALR 303 at 307; BC9507787 (not reasonable to make lengthy and slow FOI application to obtain access to CAA records); Roads and Traffic Authority of NSW v Australian National Car Parks Pty Ltd (2007) 47 MVR 502; [2007] NSWCA 114; BC200703632 at [14] (postulated FOI Act request — not reasonably required).

level.toc-caption: [5.2.10] For the purpose of commencing proceedings

heading.title: For the purpose of commencing proceedings

p.text: The application must be to obtain identification information necessary for the purpose of commencing proceedings against the person sought to be identified. That requirement means that an applicant will have to satisfy the court the proposed claim has an apparently sustainable basis, and that the application is genuinely made for the purpose of making the claim: Stewart v Miller [1979] 2 NSWLR 128 ; Exley v Wyong Shire Council , (SC(NSW), Allen M, 9 December 1976, unreported). (Compare P v T Ltd [1997] 4 All ER 200; [1997] 1 WLR 1309 where the discovery was ordered of allegations of misconduct for the purpose of allowing the plaintiff to assess whether they gave rise to a cause of action against the complainant.) The applicant will also have to satisfy the court that “the other person” (ie the person required to provide preliminary discovery) may have relevant identification information or documents: Roads & Traffic Authority (NSW) v Australian National Car Parks Pty Ltd (2007) 47 MVR 502; [2007] NSWCA 114; BC200703632 at [14].

The applicant’s must satisfy the court that they desire to commence proceedings against the “other person”. But that desire to commence proceedings does not have to be reflected in an immutably fixed or unqualified intention to sue: Roads & Traffic Authority of New South Wales v Australian National Car Parks Pty Limited (2007) 47 MVR 502; [2007] NSWCA 114; BC200703632 at [12]; Roads & Traffic Authority of New South Wales v Care Park Pty Ltd [2011] NSWSC 714; BC201105117 at [13]; Roads & Traffic Authority of New South Wales v Care Park Pty Ltd [2012] NSWCA 35; BC201201170 at [108]–[112]. The rule is not to be interpreted with undue technicality: at [14].

The basic purpose of the power conferred by the present rule is to permit an applicant to obtain necessary identification information to pursue an apparently genuine cause of action: John Fairfax & Sons Ltd v Cojuangco (1988) 165 CLR 346 at 357; 82 ALR 1; 62 ALJR 640; BC8802649 . Consequently, in the exercise of the power it is relevant to consider whether the applicant has an apparently effective cause of action against persons other than the person whose identity is sought to be disclosed: H & H Security Pty Ltd v Toliopoulos (NSWSC, Levine J, 20789/94, 17 May 1995, unreported, BC9504576): Liu v Age Co Ltd (2012) 285 ALR 386; 257 FLR 360; [2012] NSWSC 12; BC201200265 at [128]–[141] (potential defence of qualified privilege). If the applicant has already commenced apparently effective proceedings an order will not usually be made under the present rule: Survival & Industrial Equipment (Newcastle) Pty Ltd v Owners of the Vessel “Alley Cat” (1992) 36 FCR 129 . But the mere existence of an alternative remedy or the possibility of taking other proceedings to obtain the information sought (see Roads & Traffic Authority of New South Wales v Care Park Pty Ltd [2011] NSWSC 714; BC201105117 at [14]); will not necessarily be conclusive against the application. In some kinds of proceedings, particularly defamation proceedings, the applicant may have a genuine interest in pursuing proceedings against the “person concerned” as a means of vindication: see John Fairfax & Sons Ltd v Cojuangco (1987) 8 NSWLR 145 at 151D; Liu v Age Co Ltd (2012) 285 ALR 386; 257 FLR 360; [2012] NSWSC 12; BC201200265 at [159].

The extent to which questions of necessity, and desirability, may be relevant to the exercise of the discretion conferred by the present rule can be illustrated where the application seeks the disclosure of the sources of information published in the public media. These kinds of application require consideration of the “newspaper rule” and the public interest considerations that underlie it. Two cases provide contrasting examples. In John Fairfax & Sons Ltd v Cojuangco (1988) 165 CLR 346 at 357; 82 ALR 1; 62 ALJR 640; BC8802649 the High Court upheld an order for preliminary discovery on the basis that the known potential defendants (the newspaper publisher and the journalist) had a potentially good defence to the potential defamation claim against them. After the High Court decision the publisher applied to have the original order set aside and undertook not to call the journalist at the trial. On the plaintiff’s appeal from the order setting aside the original order for preliminary discovery, the defendant further undertook not to rely upon a defence of qualified privilege. The appeal was dismissed on the basis that the undertakings rendered the discovery sought unnecessary: Cojuangco v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd (No 2) (1990) A Def R 51-005; (1991) Aust Torts Reports 81-068; BC9001753.

In Liu v Age Co Ltd (2012) 285 ALR 386; 257 FLR 360; [2012] NSWSC 12; BC201200265 the proceedings sought disclosure of the sources of information for published articles suggesting corrupt payments made by the applicant to a Minister of State. The applicant claimed that the publication relied on forged documents. The court ordered discovery under the present rule, after recognising the competing public interest in the accurate discussion of the subject matter of the articles, and in the application of the “newspaper rule”: at [162]–[170].

An application may be made involving more than one potential defendant, but any examination of the witness is restricted to matters of identification of the proposed defendants. It is not to be carried out for the purpose of determining the relative culpability of various prospective defendants: Taylor v Osborne [1973] 1 NSWLR 52 ; National Education Advancement Programs (NEAP) Pty Ltd v Ashton (1995) 33 IPR 281; 128 FLR 334; BC9506806 .
Legislation cited in [5.2.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Law Reform (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1946 s 6.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 500(2).

It is generally inappropriate to join an insurer as a defendant if there is no liability issue between the insurer and the insured defendant: Beneficial Finance Corp Ltd v Price Waterhouse (1996) 68 SASR 19; 189 LSJS 364; BC9606539 . However, s 6 of the Law Reform (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1946 creates a direct cause of action, subject to leave, against a wrongdoer’s insurer. If proceedings against the insurer are necessary to provide the plaintiff with an effective remedy, including cases where the defendant may not otherwise have the means to satisfy the judgment, preliminary discovery to obtain the identity of the insurer is potentially available under the present rule: Perpetual Trustee Co Ltd v Wilkins [2001] NSWSC 1192; BC200108184 . Similarly, an insured defendant’s apparent lack of means will permit the grant of leave under s 6 of the Law Reform (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1946: Spain v Metropolitan Meat Industry Board [1971] 1 NSWLR 91 at 97 ; Cambridge Credit Corp Ltd v Lissenden (1987) 8 NSWLR 411 at 420 . If the insured defendant is already in liquidation, or been declared bankrupt, any claim for preliminary discovery of insurance documents should be brought against the liquidator (or trustee in bankruptcy): Criminale v TRN Security Services Pty Ltd (In Liq) [2008] NSWSC 562; BC200804325 at [29] [34] per Barrett J (a claim for preliminary discovery against a company in liquidation was refused as was an order for leave to proceed under s 500(2) of the Corporations Act 2001 (Cth)).

An order refusing an application for preliminary discovery has been held to be an interlocutory order and thus any appeal from such a refusal requires leave: Malouf v Malouf (1999) 86 FCR 134 at 143; 167 ALR 383 at 391; [1999] FCA 284; BC9901180 .

The rule, in so far as it potentially applies to require disclosure of information relating to the discussion of government and political matters, does not invalidly infringe the implied constitutional freedom of political discussion: Liu v Age Co Ltd (2012) 285 ALR 386; 257 FLR 360; [2012] NSWSC 12; BC201200265 at [14]–[61].

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 5.3] r 5.3 Discovery of documents from prospective defendant (cf Federal Court Rules, Order 15A, rules 6, 7 and 9)

leg:heading.title: Discovery of documents from prospective defendant (cf Federal Court Rules, Order 15A, rules 6 , 7 and 9 )

p.text: If it appears to the court that:

the applicant may be entitled to make a claim for relief from the court against a person (the prospective defendant) but, having made reasonable inquiries, is unable to obtain sufficient information to decide whether or not to commence proceedings against the prospective defendant, and
the prospective defendant may have or have had possession of a document or thing that can assist in determining whether or not the applicant is entitled to make such a claim for relief, and
inspection of such a document would assist the applicant to make the decision concerned.

The court may order that the prospective defendant must give discovery to the applicant of all documents that are or have been in the person’s possession and that relate to the question of whether or not the applicant is entitled to make a claim for relief.
An order under this rule with respect to any document held by a corporation may be addressed to any officer or former officer of the corporation.
Unless the court orders otherwise, an application for an order under this rule:
must be supported by an affidavit stating the facts on which the applicant relies and specifying the kinds of documents in respect of which the order is sought, and
must, together with a copy of the supporting affidavit, be served personally on the person to whom it is addressed.

This rule applies, with any necessary modification, where the applicant, being a party to proceedings, wishes to decide whether or not to claim or cross-claim against a person who is not a party to the proceedings.
[r 5.3 am Amendment 1 of 2005 r 3 and Sch 1[8], effective 15 August 2005]
Legislation cited in [5.3.2] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 5.3(1), r 5.3(1)(a), r 5.3(2), r 5.3(3).

Preliminary discovery under the present rule only applies for the purpose of intended proceedings against the person from whom discovery is sought. It does not permit discovery for the purpose of prospective claims against other parties, nor discovery for the purpose of assessing the capacity of the proposed defendant to satisfy a judgment: Glencore International AG v Selwyn Mines Ltd (2005) 223 ALR 238; [2005] FCA 801; BC200504165 at [106] . Entitlement to an order for preliminary discovery requires satisfaction of all 5 factors set out in r 5.3(1) . It must appear to the court that:
Inspection of that document or thing would assist the applicant to decide whether or not to commence proceedings: r 5.3(3) .

Even if the applicant has satisfied the criteria in UCPR 5.3, there is a residual discretionary decision whether an order for preliminary discovery should be made: Hatfield v TCN Channel Nine Pty Ltd (2010) 77 NSWLR 506; [2010] NSWCA 69; BC201001990 at [104]–[109] and [124], [154], [162] (no preliminary discovery to consider prospects of success in obtaining an interim injunction to restrain defamatory broadcast).

level.toc-caption: [5.3.5] Satisfaction of applicant’s entitlement to make the substantive claim

heading.title: Satisfaction of applicant’s entitlement to make the substantive claim

p.text: The rule potentially applies if the court is satisfied the applicant “may be entitled to make a claim”. That degree of satisfaction will arise where an applicant can demonstrate a reasonable objective basis for the proposed claim: Hooper v Kirella Pty Ltd (1999) 96 FCR 1; 167 ALR 358; [1999] FCA 1584; BC9907490 ; Glencore International AG v Selwyn Mines Ltd (2005) 223 ALR 238; [2005] FCA 801; BC200504165 at [16], [91], [96], [105] . But the rule is required to be liberally construed: Hatfield v TCN Channel Nine Pty Ltd (2010) 77 NSWLR 506 ; [2010] NSWCA 69; BC201001990 at [52]. The requisite satisfaction may arise even if the applicant cannot articulate a prima facie or pleadable case. The material capable of providing the required satisfaction must involve more than mere assertion, suspicion or conjecture. It must provide some reasonable cause to believe the applicant has a right of action. It must be sufficient to establish belief in the probability, as distinct from the mere possibility, of a cause of action: Hatfield v TCN Channel Nine Pty Ltd (2010) 77 NSWLR 506 ; [2010] NSWCA 69; BC201001990 at [47]–[51]; Panasonic Australia Pty Ltd v Ngage Pty Ltd (2006) 69 IPR 595; [2006] NSWSC 399; BC200603145 at [20], [22] and [27]; Morton v Nylex Ltd [2007] NSWSC 562; BC200704257 at [25]–[31] (appeared to the court that cause of action may exist and plaintiffs may be entitled to relief under s 233 of the Corporations Act 2001).

In addition, the scope of the application is not limited to the availability of a cause of action. It extends to obtaining sufficient information to make a decision whether to commence proceedings. Thus documents showing either the possible existence of defences, or the likely amount of any recoverable damages, may be discoverable under UCPR r 5.3: Hatfield v TCN Channel Nine Pty Ltd (2010) 77 NSWLR 506; [2010] NSWCA 69; BC201001990 at [51]; Morton v Nylex Ltd [2007] NSWSC 562; BC200704257 . The rule is to be beneficially construed, given the fullest scope that its language will reasonably allow, with the proper brake on any excesses lying in the discretion of the court, exercised in the particular circumstances of each case.

The power to make an order under the present rule is preconditioned on the applicants being able to show that after “having made reasonable inquiries” they still lack sufficient information to decide whether or not to commence proceedings against a prospective defendant. The scope of the potential discovery obligation that may be imposed by an order under the present rule is significant. For that reason, the precondition of “reasonable inquiry” is an important consideration. Reasonable inquiries are not restricted to inquiries made of the prospective defendant: Papaconstuntinos v Holmes a Court [2006] NSWSC 945; BC200607317 (proposed defamation proceedings — application refused). The determination of what is reasonable must take into account any relationship between the applicant and the prospective defendant: Sinopharm Jiangsu Co Pty Ltyd v Bank of China [2007] NSWSC 484; BC200703527 at [32] (no inquiries made of the bank in foreign country where events seemed to have taken place — application refused).

level.toc-caption: [5.3.15] Absence of sufficient information to decide to commence proceedings

heading.title: Absence of sufficient information to decide to commence proceedings

p.text: An applicant must disclose what information they already have relevant to making a decision, and identify what information is lacking. Preliminary discovery cannot be used to build up a case which an applicant has already decided, or could decide to bring: Morton v Nylex Pty Ltd [2007] NSWSC 562; BC200704257 at [32] ff. Consequently a party that has already asserted an entitlement to commence substantive proceedings cannot sustain an application for preliminary discovery under the present rule: Contour Building and Construction Pty Ltd v Kerr [2008] NSWSC 883; BC200807668 . Nevertheless the “sufficiency” of available information is not confined to consideration of whether or not the applicant has an apparently arguable basis for the proposed proceedings. It extends to permit some consideration of the applicant’s likely prospects of success — at least to the extent of exploring potentially available defences: Hatfield v TCN Channel Nine Pty Ltd (2010) 77 NSWLR 506; [2010] NSWCA 69; BC201001990 at [51]; Papaconstuntinos v Holmes a Court [2006] NSWSC 945; BC200607317 at [16]–[17] ; CGU Insurance Ltd v Malaysia International Shipping Corp Berhad (2001) 187 ALR 279; [2001] FCA 1223; BC200105976 .

level.toc-caption: [5.3.20] Application required to be made on notice

p.text: Legislation cited in [5.3.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 25.3.

heading.title: Application required to be made on notice

p.text: The procedure provided for in this rule, especially given the requirement for personal service on the prospective defendant, assumes the defendant’s probable ultimate compliance with any order that may be made. Where such an assumption is unwarranted, or where the circumstances involve urgency, a preservation application ought be made under UCPR r 25.3 : see especially [25.3.20] (Anton Piller orders).
Legislation cited in [5.3.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 42.1.

There is the further possibility that costs a party incurs in producing documents in response to an order for preliminary discovery may (merely) anticipate costs it would otherwise incur if and when proceedings are ultimately commenced. Differing views have been expressed about the extent to which costs of those kind should be recovered in the preliminary discovery proceedings, or abide the result of any subsequent substantive proceedings. See C7 Pty Ltd v Foxtel Management Pty Ltd [2001] FCA 1864; BC200108239 at [50] and Andrews Advertising Pty Ltd v Andrews [2011] NSWSC 244; BC201102173 (production costs ordered); compare Newcrest Mining Ltd v Apache Northwest Pty Ltd (No 2) [2008] FCA 1663; BC200809893 (costs conditionally deferred).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 5.4] r 5.4 Discovery of documents from other persons (cf Federal Court Rules, Order 15A, rule 8)

leg:heading.title: Discovery of documents from other persons (cf Federal Court Rules, Order 15A, rule 8 )

p.text: The court may order that a person who is not a party to proceedings, but in respect of whom it appears to the court that the person may have or have had possession of a document that relates to any question in the proceedings, must give discovery to the applicant of all documents that are or have been in the person’s possession and that relate to that question.
Unless the court orders otherwise, an application for an order under this rule:
must be supported by an affidavit stating the facts on which the applicant relies and specifying the kinds of documents in respect of which the order is sought, and
must, together with a copy of the supporting affidavit, be served personally on the person to whom it is addressed.
[r 5.4 am Amendment 1 of 2005 r 3 and Sch 1[9], effective 15 August 2005]

Before an order for discovery can properly be made against a non-party under the present rule, the applicant must first satisfy the court about the non-party’s probable possession of the documents, and that they do “relate to” questions in the proceedings: Dover Fisheries Pty Ltd v Bottrill Research Pty Ltd (1995) ¶AIPC 91-158; BC9400599 . That relationship requirement depends on the current state of the pleadings, rather than issues intended to be raised by proposed amendments: Zahos v Michael [2012] NSWSC 195; BC201203471 at [27]–[30] per Hulme J.

Conversely, a respondent to a non-party discovery application is entitled to make a meaningful assessment of whether documents in its possession do actually relate to any question in the proceedings. That entitlement will usually require disclosure of any pleadings. But it does not entail the non-party having any status to challenge pleaded allegations or seek further particulars: Fuelsave Pty Ltd v Perentie Holdings Pty Ltd [2007] NSWSC 1497; BC200711737 .

A respondent to a non-party’s possession of documents that relate to a question in the proceedings, the rule potentially imposes a significantly greater production obligation than would an appropriately worded subpoena (because of the conventional prohibition against “fishing” and the consequential requirement for reasonable particularity). In practice, the discovery obligation imposed will generally only extend to specified “kinds of documents”. The description of the documents will generally be made by reference to some objective criterion (such as date, author addressee, type or subject matter) rather than by reference to issues in the proceedings.

The purpose of the power to order discovery against a non-party is to facilitate the just and proper determination of the issues in the proceedings: Dover Fisheries Pty Ltd v Bottrill (1995) AIPC ¶91–158; BC9400599 . An implied corollary of that proposition is that an applicant ought usually demonstrate that the documents sought are both necessary and not available from the other parties to the proceedings: Tipperary Developments Pty Ltd v Western Australia (1999) 21 WAR 250; [1999] WASC 62; BC9903446 ; Richardson Pacific Ltd v Fielding (1990) 26 FCR 188 at 189 ; Evans Deakin Pty Limited v Sebel Furniture Ltd [2001] FCA 1772; BC200107956 , Allsop J (for instance where a third party holds the only copies of particular documents: Williams Aviation Pty Ltd v Santos Ltd (1985) 40 SASR 272 ). It will not ordinarily be appropriate to order discovery against an expert witness for an opposing party: Casley-Smith v Evan and the District Council of Stirling (No 11) (1989) 151 LSJS 357.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 5.5] r 5.5 Discovery and inspection generally (cf Federal Court Rules, Order 15A, rule 10)

leg:heading.title: Discovery and inspection generally (cf Federal Court Rules, Order 15A, rule 10 )

p.text: Division 1 of Part 21 applies to and in respect of the discovery and inspection of documents the subject of an order for discovery under this part in the same way as it applies to the discovery and inspection of documents the subject of an order for discovery under that division.
See also rule 23.8 with respect to inspection of property.
[r 5.5 am Amendment 1 of 2005 r 3 and Sch 1[10], effective 15 August 2005]

level.toc-caption: [5.5.5] Form of discovery and obligation to produce for inspection

p.text: Legislation cited in [5.5.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 21.1(2), r 5.4.

heading.title: Form of discovery and obligation to produce for inspection

p.text: The present rule is not intended to enlarge the scope of the discovery obligation imposed by an order under r 5.4 — despite the arguably wider concept of “relevance to a fact in issue” referred to in r 21.1(2) . The present rule is concerned with the manner in which the non-party discovery obligation is performed. This involves the court’s power to order discovery by reference to classes of documents, the obligation to produce documents for inspection, the obligation to use the documents only for the purpose of the proceedings, and the restriction of discovery in personal injury proceedings.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 5.6] r 5.6 Security for costs (cf Federal Court Rules, Order 15A, rule 11)

leg:heading.title: Security for costs (cf Federal Court Rules, Order 15A, rule 11 )

p.text: An order under this Part may be made subject to a condition requiring the applicant to give security for the costs of the person against whom the order is made.
[r 5.6 am Amendment 1 of 2005 r 3 and Sch 1[11], effective 15 August 2005]

If security is ordered, it will usually be required in an amount that will provide a complete indemnity. If the security amount appears inadequate, the non-party “discoveree” can apply, with supporting evidence establishing the probable insufficiency: Jovista Pty Ltd v FAI General Insurance Co Ltd [1999] WASC 44; BC9902981 at [13] ; to have the security amount increased: Davis v Sagar Pty Ltd (WASC, Sanderson M, Lib No 980443, 10 August 1998, unreported, BC9803745).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 5.7] r 5.7 Privilege (cf Federal Court Rules, Order 15A, rule 2)

leg:heading.title: Privilege (cf Federal Court Rules, Order 15A, rule 2 )

p.text: An order under this Part does not operate so as to require the person against whom it is made to produce any privileged document that the person could not be required to produce:
if the applicant had commenced proceedings against that person, or
if that person had otherwise become a party to proceedings to which the applicant is a party, or
if the person had been served with a subpoena for production of the document in proceedings to which the applicant is a party.
[r 5.7 am Amendment 1 of 2005 r 3 and Sch 1[12], effective 15 August 2005]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 5.8] r 5.8 Costs and other expenses (cf SCR Part 52A, rule 26; DCR Part 39A, rule 5; Federal Court Rules, Order 15A, rules 4 and 11)

p.text: On any application for an order under this Part, the court may make orders for the costs of the applicant, of the person against whom the order is made or sought and of any other party to the proceedings.
The costs in respect of which such an order may be made include:
payment of conduct money, and
payments made on account of any expense or loss in relation to the proceedings, and
the costs of making and serving any list of documents, and
the costs of producing any documents for inspection, and

the costs of otherwise complying with the requirements of any order under Division 1 of Part 21 , as applying to the discovery and inspection of documents the subject of an order for discovery under this Part.
[r 5.8 am Amendment 1 of 2005 r 3 and Sch 1[13], effective 15 August 2005]

level.toc-caption: [5.8.5] Expenses of applicant and costs orders

heading.title: Expenses of applicant and costs orders

p.text: Differing views have been expressed about the costs entitlement of a third party who unsuccessfully opposes an application for discovery under the present rule. There are authorities in favour of the view that the costs of a disputed application for preliminary discovery will be awarded in accordance with the usual rule that costs follow the event: Airways Corp of New Zealand v Present Partners of Price Waterhouse Coopers Legal [2002] NSWSC 521; BC200203174 ; Jovista Pty Ltd v FAI General Insurance Co Ltd [1999] WASC 44; BC9902981 at [6] . There are also authorities that the third party has at least a presumed entitlement to the costs of appearing in response to the application for discovery: Council of the City of Sydney v Goldspar Pty Ltd [2003] FCA 769; BC200303968 at [5] (contrast the practice stated by the English Court of Appeal in Totalise plc v The Motley Fool Ltd [2001] All ER (D) 213 (Feb); [2001] TLR 208 .) However, the expenses of complying with the order for discovery, such as the costs of locating and producing the documents and information sought, and any costs of obtaining related legal advice, are recoverable in the same way as those incurred by any person who complies with a subpoena for the production of documents: Airways Corp of New Zealand v Present Partners of Price Waterhouse Coopers Legal , above.
